posts.link-text: Apartment Therapy Unplggd: Garrett Murray's Stylish Home Office
posts.link-description: I have to admit, I’m probably happier than I should be about my home office shots being featured at Apartment Therapy. I’ve been reading the Unplggd section (especially the house tours) for quite some time, and to be included on the site is pretty great.

posts.regular-body:
New Home Office, Vertical (View bigger at Flickr)

My home office in New Jersey is almost completely set up now. More photos soon. In the mean time, it’s snowing out (again) and my view is quite nice.

posts.conversation-text:
Brian Warren: You're in New Jersey now?
Brian Warren: Our states border. I feel so close to you.
Me: Yep, in NJ now.
Me: And I've always felt close to you.
Brian Warren: Awwww. SOB.
Brian Warren: sniff
Me: I thought you just called me a son of a bitch.
Brian Warren: You: I've always felt close to you. Me: You son of a bitch.
Me: Seemed about right.

posts.link-description: A “vintage terminal emulator” that looks spectacular. I don’t spend a ton of time in Terminal, but even the few minutes per day are made better by this nicely designed app.

posts.question:
Garret, I've got my first meeting with my first big client in 3 hours. I've been doing mostly simple web design with the obvious Wordpress integration blah blah blah. This client's project is what I would like to be doing, creating real web applications.

I was wondering if you have any tips for me on how to handle myself in the meeting. I'm young, but outgoing and have no issue to talking to some one older than me, especially if I actually know about the subject I'm talking about. I know you've worked with clients big and small, cough Gourmet Live cough, and any advice you can give on communicating with some one that is about to entrust you with their final product would be great!

ps. Thanks so much for blogging as often as you do, its like a little surprise once a month...
posts.answer:
The best advice I can offer is to be succinct and honest. While it’s fine to bite off more than you can chew, you should only be accepting work you can actually do—i.e., it’s one thing to accept a project that is going to force you to work 70 hours a week (doable), it’s another to accept one that will force you to learn a new language/technology in under two weeks (not doable). I’m not saying you’re doing the latter, but most young people who are trying to land their first large project tend to get themselves into a hole by promising stuff they can’t deliver on in hopes of locking in the job (I’ve done this before).

Assuming you can handle the work, during the meeting you need to be clear about your strengths, why you’d be good for the project, and how you foresee doing the actual work. Don’t make a lot of excuses for why you haven’t done large projects in the past—everyone has to start somewhere.

And if you don’t get the job, don’t be too deflated. There are plenty of other projects out there, and eventually, if you do good work, you’ll start getting them.

posts.question: Questions, answers, please!
posts.answer:
Twist my arm why don’t you? But fine: Here’re some burning answers to your non-burning questions. First, from Anonymous and several of his friends:

Like any Apple Fanboy, you seem to buy every new product the company announces. At this point, what are all the Apple products you own at the moment?

Oh, sure, I’d love to answer an insulting question from someone who uses the term “fanboy”. In fact, I can answer it very easily: I own nearly every consumer product Apple makes. And, I bought them without thinking. I just buy anything they make because I’m a pinhead and I can’t make up my own mind. If only I loved Linux or Microsoft or Dell as much as I love Apple! Then I wouldn’t be a fanboy and I could fill my house with carefully selected, cheap, plastic products that are user-unfriendly and break easily. Life would be so much better!

If I move to New York will you hang out with me?

It’s nice of you to ask, and I’d love to say yes, but you just missed me. Sorry! Perhaps in 2016?

Your girlfriend is very cute. Is she puerto-rican? Do you mind me asking is she a lot younger than you?

Thanks, I agree, she is very cute. But she’s not Puerto Rican and she’s not younger than me. In fact, she’s older than me. I call her my “old lady” and I say things like, “Hey, you’re old.” Sometimes I kick her cane out from under her or push the button on her medic-alert bracelet to call the paramedics just to josh her. She doesn’t think this is funny. But, since she’s not Puerto Rican, at least I don’t have to worry about her complaining constantly about the confusing state of their commonwealth political status.

Your girlfriend is hot sauce poured over sexy burrito. How’d you do it?

I agree with the sentiment, although I don’t know that I would have chosen those words. How’d I do it? I’m not sure. I guess I spent a while looking put together, acted somewhat intelligent, made some jokes, and finally got a chance to use that mind control powder I bought in 2005. It worked really well. The only side effect is that it’s slowly turning her into a Puerto Rican.

And now, some less anonymous folks:

evanwalsh: Are you going to buy the new Decemberists album?

Going to, am and did. And it’s pretty great.

caseymac: Can you recommend any resources/books/starting points for someone looking to get into iPhone/iPad app development?

I would start with:

  • Beginning iPhone 4 Development by D. Mark, J. LaMarche & J. Nutting
  • iPhone App Development: The Missing Manual by Craig Hockenberry
  • Objective-C for Absolute Beginners by G. Bennett, B. Lees & M. Fisher
  • Programming in Objective-C 2.0 by Stephen G. Kochan

Hope that helps!

ploogy: You mentioned in “Time for a Change” that you were considering alternatives to Tumblr. What alternatives have you looked at/would you recommend, other than Posterous and Wordpress?

I haven’t completely decided yet, but I’m looking at Expression Engine at this point. After reading tutorials on how to make EE work a bit like Tumblr (such as the one by Shaping the Page), and having worked with EE in the past, I think it’s the way to go for me.

As always, you can ask me a question. If you ask anonymously it takes me more time to answer, but I try to get to every question eventually.

posts.link-description:
Garrett Murray talks with Dan Benjamin about filmmaking, software development, inspiration, and the future of the web as a platform for creativity.

I had a lot of fun recording this episode and it’s apparent since I talk for about 43 minutes straight. I think Dan said a total of about 50 words.

posts.regular-title: I've Got Your Big Decision Right Here, Pal
posts.regular-body:
Hidden amongst my long answers to Dan Benjamin’s questions in my interview on The Pipeline this week, there was a fairly major announcement. Or at least major for me.

In July of this year, we’re moving to Los Angeles. That’s the short version, here’s the slightly longer version:

These past few years I have grown as a developer, a designer, and more recently as a business owner and entrepreneur. I’ve spent the last 11 years busting my ass working for various companies, building various products, and then starting two businesses of my own, including my current company, Karbon. Things have gone very well and I’m proud to be able to say that. But, at the same time, this business, this work, isn’t my only interest.

Since childhood I’ve been enamored with television and film. My earliest memories are of making home movies, performing comedy sketches with cousins and friends, and watching hours and hours of TV. My fascination continued through high school, where I wrote a television pilot and several short films, and into college where I studied electronic filmmaking and acted in as many projects as I could find. After college, though, reality set in and I needed to make money. Luckily, endless interest in computers, the internet and technology allowed me to turn my hobby of web development into a full-time job and, eventually, to running my own company today. But during the past 11 years I’ve constantly wished I could focus more time and energy on film and really try to make a career out of it.

I’m very fortunate to run the kind of business that doesn’t require an office or a specific locale. My clients are all over the globe, and it doesn’t matter where our computers are so long as there’s a reliable internet connection. So, in July, Karbon is officially moving to Los Angeles. We’ll continue to do the same kind of awesome work we’re doing now, just from a different area code. But the huge benefit will be that we can also spend time trying to make our other dreams come true, by focusing our free time on television and film work.

You’ll note I keep saying “we” which actually has two separate meanings. The first is that Shawn Morrison, who works for Karbon and whom I’ve been making films and comedy with for years, is also moving to Los Angeles. This decision to move would have been so much harder had it not been for Shawn and his wife also taking the plunge. We’ll continue to work together both at Karbon and on new film projects as we attempt to navigate the Hollywood experience. The other “we” is that I’ve somehow convinced my girlfriend Stacey I’m worth the gamble, and she’s coming with me to LA as well. She has a real, serious, respectful career and so I cannot wait to hopefully become successful in a vapid profession to even the universe back out.

In fact, the process has already begun. This past weekend, I packed up the apartment in which I had lived for eight years—the longest I have ever lived anywhere in my entire life—and moved to New Jersey into Stacey’s apartment. Her spacious place will serve us well as a temporary home until we pack everything up and ship it all to the west coast in six months.

I love New York, and I cannot imagine not living in the city again at some point, but for now the time has come to be adventurous and try what I’ve never had the guts to try before. After all, time’s a wasting.

posts.photo-caption:
Why have I been keeping these old boxes? (View at Flickr)

Some of them are as old as 8 years. Sadly, after I took this photo, I destroyed them all.

posts.question:
According to Flickr, you take a lot of naps with your pet cats.
Would you say this is an accurate description of your life?
posts.answer: Not exactly. Because we now have four cats, it seems no matter where I take a picture in the apartment, a cat is there. And while recent photo highlights have included me, in bed, with cats, I can assure you that’s not where I spend most of my time. I just don’t take photos of me sitting at my desk for 10 hours a day. But perhaps I should.

posts.regular-body:
Here’s the frustrating thing about Tumblr: If you ignore all the downtime, errors, server outages and all that annoying stuff, which took sites down for nearly two full days recently and still continues to crop up regularly—if you somehow ignore all of that—simple things still don’t work properly, like the queue.

I use the queue for Prettify* so that I can do lots of future content pre-loading. In fact, Prettify* is currently scheduled with content releases for the next several months. Each post is scheduled for a specific time and date. But then today, for no reason, Tumblr just arbitrarily published some of the scheduled posts at random times. An item scheduled for Thursday at 10AM published itself today at 4PM. Sure, why not? That doesn’t ruin my plans at all.

If you have a feature called a queue, and it allows you to schedule posts, then it had better work. Otherwise, get rid of it. The queue has been buggy and problematic since its launch and even the “new queue”, released in October, did not fix these problems.

I loved Tumblr for the first few years I used it, but these days it feels like headache after headache. Sadly, I have begun to plan for alternate options and will eventually move my site to a different platform. While I’m sure the folks at Tumblr are working on these problems, the amount of time wasted in the past year alone on bugs, outages and frustration are hardly worth it any longer.

2010 was a great year for iOS—here’s my list of the apps I couldn’t live without the past 12 months. Even though we worked on several iPad projects last year, I didn’t use the iPad much outside of work, so while some of my favorites are universal apps, most of these are iPhone (and iPod Touch) applications.

My Favorite App of 2010

Instagram (Free)
I was hooked immediately. So were millions of other people. Instagram is the perfect formula of photography and social networking. Even without the photo filters included, I think Instagram would have been successful—they’re like frosting on the cake. Instagram makes it easy to share your photos (and make them look even better) with friends and strangers, as well as find new friends to follow. Simple like and comment functionality adds just the right amount of social interaction. I spend way too much time every day thinking about photos to take for Instagram, and just as many browsing friends’ photostreams. If you have an iPhone and you aren’t using Instagram, you’re a damned fool. (You can find me in Instagram with the username garrettmurray.)

Favorite Photography Apps

TiltShiftGen (99¢, free demo)
I rarely use TiltShiftGen the way it was intended (to create the tilt-shift effect)—instead, I use it to give a nice depth to photos taken with the iPhone that otherwise look very flat. TSG’s simple blur functionality (radial or linear) allows for changing both the strength of the blur as well as the distance, and it’s dead-simple to use. Granted, you have to be careful not to go overboard, but TSG is invaluable for classing up normal, flat iPhone photos.

Camera+ (99¢)
Recently re-released to the App Store after many months away for breaking App Store rules, Camera+ returned with a new UI (which is much better than version 1’s) and new features. Camera+ is perfect for taking photos in less-than-ideal light situations because of its two-finger “touch exposure and focus” functionality, which allows you to use one finger to set focus and a second finger to choose where the camera should meter for light. This allows you to take more balanced photos than the native Camera app. In addition, Camera+ features lots of nice built-in filter and editing tools, as well as a new in-app-purchasable set of filters called “I <3 Analog” which includes some really great settings.

Favorite Apps I Use Daily

Reeder ($2.99)
There isn’t much to say about Reeder, which is a testament to how good it is. It’s pretty much the perfect newsreader. The iOS app is sharp, simple and feature-rich without being in your face about it. (And the new in-beta OS X app is pretty great too.)

Gowalla (Free)
By now, nearly everyone either uses Gowalla or knows what it is. These days, I use it mostly as a way to track where I’ve been and less as a social game as it was once intended. I enjoy collecting items and pins, but more so I enjoy being able to see a list of everywhere I’ve been in the past few years. As a data junky, this kind of thing is fun to have. And Gowalla’s recent redesign is gorgeous.

Articles ($2.99)
Wikipedia presented beautifully with searching, tabs and more. I use Articles at least a few times a day to settle arguments, read about various historical events, and get behind-the-scenes information about the production of various movies I’ve recently seen.

Favorite New App of 2010

Screens ($14.99)
It’s crazy to say this, but Screens is a fully-functional, beautiful VNC app for iOS that actually works and works well. That I can control my computer from my iPhone is old news (apps like TouchPad and its competitors have been doing this for quite some time), but that I can actually see my screen and use my computer from across the room, on a 3.5-inch screen, without being frustrated, is amazing.

Favorite Games

Infinity Blade ($5.99)
If you had shown me Infinity Blade even 5 years ago and told me it was running on a phone I would have punched you in the face and stolen your phone. Infinity Blade is an amazing technical achievement, with sharp, highly detailed graphics, great sound, and a smooth framerate. It also happens to be a fun game with a simple but solid leveling-up mechanic, inventory system and other RPG elements. The story is dead-simple (basically one line of script), but the battles are fun and I kept playing even after I beat it just to keep leveling up my character. Infinity Blade is not only a great game, but it truly feels like the beginning of some amazing things that will happen in the iOS gamespace in the next few months and years.

Mr. AahH!! (99¢)
Let’s ignore the title of this game for a moment, because it’s ridiculous. Putting that aside, Mr. AahH!! is a terrific play-when-you-have-a-spare-moment game. It’s addictive, simple, challenging and fun. Watch a little character swing from platform to platform and touch the screen when he should let go of the rope. Land him on platforms and try to get him as close to the middle as you can. Added challenges when wind and different levels of gravity are involved. Stupid-simple fun.

Osmos (99¢)
A beautiful game with a terrific atmospheric soundtrack. Osmos involves all sorts of challenges and includes a large number of levels with varying degrees of difficulty, as well as an unlockable arcade mode. There were levels I played that took me 40+ tries, but I never got frustrated—I just kept trying different strategies. A remarkably soothing gameplay experience, considering how complex some of the levels can be.

StarDunk (Free)
In a nutshell, StarDunk is a massively multiplayer online basket shooting game. There are a few additions (different ball types with different features, various in-game bonuses like shooting three balls at once for a time), but at its core, this is that carnival game of shooting as many baskets as you can in a set time, only with hundreds of other people playing at the same time. It’s addictive, simple, and fun. (You can play offline as well, if you don’t have an internet connection.)

posts.question: Seeing a designer/developer's homescreen is like looking at porn. When can we see an updated shot?
posts.answer: I upload to Homescreen.me here and there. The current shot is I’ve got there is recent and up-to-date: http://homescreen.me/garrettmurray

posts.question: In every other photograph of you, I noticed you're always wearing a hoodie which leads me to classify you as a "hoodie whore". Where do you mostly shop for them?
posts.answer: I think it’s fair to call me a hoodie whore. I wear one nearly every day. I have hoodies from American Apparel, Urban Outfitters, Ben Sherman, Burton, Esprit, Express Men and Ugmonk. Basically, nearly every store on earth.

posts.photo-caption:
Seriously?

I can’t believe Apple still hasn’t changed this icon for bluetooth headset power level indication. Currently, it looks like a crack pipe. Flip it upside down, and it wouldn’t (although then it looks a bit like a leaking water spout). Better still: Don’t use this icon, use something else.

Ridiculously Cute Napping (View bigger on Flickr)

This happened the other night. Stacey’s such a heavy sleeper that I was able to get my camera, adjust the lights, and take several pictures. And seriously, how huge is Phoenix (the cat)? What a monster.

posts.question: i meant to ask, do you use the reversed click set up on your mouse. ie with the primary click on the right and the secondary on the left, or do you just use the standard set up with primary click under your middle finger and secondary under your index? if that makes sense....basically did you flip it around?
posts.answer:
I use the mouse in my left hand, but with the default, right-handed button layout. So I primary click with my middle finger and right-click with my index finger.

It sounds weird, but after using a mouse with my right hand for many years, my brain is wired to think of mouse buttons as primary-to-the-left, secondary-to-the-right. When I first switched to left-handed mousing, I tried the left layout and found that it felt like I had to think about clicking the opposite side of what my brain expected. Was just easier to go with the default layout and use the wrong fingers.

posts.question: If that's you in the photo with the holiday cards, you're a lefty? I hope so.
posts.answer:
That is me, and I am indeed left-handed. While current statistics show only 8-15% of the population is left-handed, I have to admit we’ve got some pretty awesome folks on our side. Aside from the obvious ones (current US President Obama is a lefty), did you know that Dan Aykroyd, Robert DeNiro, Jerry Seinfeld and Bruce Willis were left-handed? Not only that, but apparently Alexander the Great and Julius Caesar were also lefties.

Being left-handed is like being in a club. I don’t know a lot of left-handed people, and I always remember people I’ve met who are. And still, to this day, whenever I sign something in front of a stranger or friend for the first time, they say, “Hey! You’re left-handed!” and then tell me people a cousin or brother or friend they have who is also a southpaw.

Of course, there are drawbacks. When I was in school and they started teaching us to use computers, they forced me to the use the mouse with my right hand (I eventually switched to my left years later), and I learned out to switch hit in baseball because the gym teacher refused to let me hit lefty in school, but I hit lefty at home. To this day, I can only throw a frisbee with my right hand for some reason. And, a lot of us write with our arms at an awful, curled angle because otherwise we smear the ink across the page.
